prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
* Spectral window widths: we have lines several hundreds of km/s wide, so we have chosen window widths on this basis.
* Velocity resolution: we propose to observe at about 2 km/s resolution in case we need to examine strongest emitting gas for our "re-weighing" technique. However, we will smooth this to 17 km/s for most purposes and have performed the sensitivity calculation with this user smoothing. We performed some spectral averaging to lower the data rate.

* Angular resolution and largest-scale of interest: We have chosen an angular resolution of 0.12" in order to get close to resolving the black hole sphere of interest and the maser disk, but without going to very long baselines or Band 9. Our largest angular scale of interest corresponds to some tens of parsecs, which is ideal for this work.

* Velocity resolution and band width used for sensitivity: we propose to observe at about 2 km/s resolution in case we need to examine strongest emitting gas for our "re-weighing" technique. However, we will smooth this to 17 km/s for most purposes and have performed the sensitivity calculation with this user smoothing.
* Sensitivity calculation: we need to be careful to achieve sufficient surface brightness sensitivity when going to approx. 0.12" resolution.
Sensitivity calculation:
Krips et al. observed the NGC 1068 CO 3-2 using the SMA. The 1sigma rms sensitivity was 51 mJy in a 1" beam, in velocity channels of 17 km/s, and we want to achieve similar surface brightness sensitivity in an ALMA 0.12" synthesised beam. Assuming the CO is distributed smoothly, then for our 0.12" ALMA beam we estimate we need 1 sigma rms of about 0.69 mJy, measured in 17 km/s. For NGC 4945 and Circinus we have checked in the literature that the same parameters will enable us to map gas at 0.12", for NGC 4388 we have examined unpublished IRAM 30-m data.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Extragalactic water masers in AGN central engines (so-called megamasers) probe either the AGN accretion disk at radii < 1 pc from the supermassive black hole, or the AGN jet -- ISM interaction, or in some targets both. They tend to be found in Compton-thick Seyfert 2 objects, and, because they can be mapped with milli-arcsecond resolution using radio VLBI at 22 GHz, they have proven to be very useful tools for determining the structures in the central parsecs of their host galaxies. In this proposal, we request to observe four megamaser galaxies with the goal of exploring the AGN Unified Model. In addition, we aim to determine if we can utilise a new mass determination method for measuring the super-massive black hole masses in these galaxies.
This proposal is a re-submission of 2013.1.01307.S (PI: Humphreys), that was awarded Cycle 2 priority B time, but which has not yet been observed. We have added additional targets to the new submission. If any targets are observed at Cycle 2, we do not need the data for these targets again at Cycle 3.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics, Astronomy and Mathematics, Hertfordshire, University of
Astrophysical Sciences Department and Observatory, Princeton University
